original_data.question: A 7-day-old infant boy presents to an emergency department due to poor feeding. His parents are recent immigrants to the United States. He was born in a traditional home birth and has never seen a medical provider. Mom had no prenatal care, has no medical issues, and is unvaccinated. The baby had been breastfeeding well until 24 hours ago when mom noticed he started having trouble latching. In the last 12 hours, he has completely refused to feed. He has had a decreased number of wet diapers and has stooled twice in the last 24 hours. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. On exam, the infant has increased tone, a clenched jaw, no head lag, and clenched hands. Initial screening bloodwork is normal. What is the most likely organism causing this infant's presentation?

model_response:
This is a case of neonatal tetanus. The infant's age, poor feeding, altered tone, and increased respiratory rate are all consistent with neonatal tetanus. The increased tone, clenched jaw, and clenched hands are all characteristic of a "trismus" or "risus sardonicus" presentation. The mother did not receive prenatal care, so she did not receive a tetanus booster, which would have protected the infant. Clostridium botulinum causes botulism, which is associated with a descending paralysis. Group B streptococcus can cause sepsis in neonates, but it is not associated with trismus. Listeria monocytogenes can cause meningitis in infants, but it is not associated with trismus.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
An individual who changes his place of residency from one country to another.
A country in NORTH AMERICA between CANADA and MEXICO.
The event of being born.
Childbirth taking place in the home.
An individual test result's deviation from the median.
Care provided the pregnant woman in order to prevent complications, and decrease the incidence of maternal and prenatal mortality.
Provision of diagnostic and/or therapeutic treatment.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
The nursing of an infant at the breast.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
An individual test result's deviation from the median.
A sudden pain, usually sharp, occurring during movement, or exacerbated by movement, and prompting cessation of movement
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
A barrier garment or padding used to absorb urine and stool, thereby helping to protect the skin and keep clothing and bedding clean.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.

An abnormal hand posture in which the hands are clenched to fists. All digits held completely flexed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. In prenatal sonography of the fetal clenched hand, the index finger overlaps a clenched fist formed by the other digits. The proximal interphalangeal articulation of the index finger is flexed and ulnarly deviated, and the thumb is adducted. [HPO:sdoelken, PMID:10085502, PMID:16702456]
Procedures performed on people to identify those who have NEOPLASMS or PRENEOPLASTIC CONDITIONS.
A living entity.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
